title: AB 2676
content:
The State of California enacts the following. Section 17052.6 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow a credit against the "net tax" for expenses related to household and dependent care services necessary for gainful employment. The credit amount is determined based on the Internal Revenue Code, with a percentage of the allowable federal credit without considering federal tax liability. For taxable years before January 1, 2003, the percentage of the allowable federal credit is determined for the net tax credit related to household and dependent care services for gainful employment. Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of the federal credit for household and dependent care services for gainful employment. The credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower percentages or no credit at all. Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of the federal credit for household and dependent care services for gainful employment. The credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower percentages or no credit at all. For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2016, the credit percentages are as follows:
- $40,000 or less: 50%
- Over $40,000 but not over $70,000: 43%
- Over $70,000 but not over $100,000: 34%
- Over $100,000: 0%
For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2019:
- $100,000 or less: 200%
- Over $100,000 but not over $125,000: 100%
- Over $125,000 but not over $150,000: 50%
- Over $150,000: 0% Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of the federal credit for household and dependent care services for gainful employment. The credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower percentages or no credit at all. For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2019, the credit percentages are as follows:
- $100,000 or less: 200%
- Over $100,000 but not over $125,000: 100%
- Over $125,000 but not over $150,000: 50%
- Over $150,000: 0%
For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2019, the credit percentages are as follows:
- $40,000 or less: 65%
- Over $40,000 but not over $70,000: 50%
- Over $70,000 but not over $100,000: 34%
- Over $100,000: 0% Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of the federal credit for household and dependent care services for gainful employment. The credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower percentages or no credit at all. For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2019, the credit percentages are as follows:
- $40,000 or less: 50%
- Over $40,000 but not over $70,000: 43%
- Over $70,000 but not over $100,000: 34%
- Over $100,000: 0% Adjusted gross income determines the percentage of the federal credit for household and dependent care services for gainful employment. The credit percentages vary based on income brackets, with higher incomes receiving lower percentages or no credit at all. For taxable years beginning on or after January 1, 2019, the credit percentages are as follows: 
- $40,000 or less: 50%
- Over $40,000 but not over $70,000: 43%
- Over $70,000 but not over $100,000: 34%
- Over $100,000: 0%
The credit authorized by this section is limited to expenses for household services and care provided in the state. The credit authorized by this section for household and dependent care services is limited to expenses for services provided in the state. Earned income subject to tax under this part is also limited to active services as a member of the Armed Forces. Earned income for active services as a member of the Armed Forces is subject to tax under this part, regardless of domicile. Qualifying individuals include children as defined in Section 152(f)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. Earned income for active services in the Armed Forces is taxable, regardless of domicile. Qualifying individuals include children as defined in Section 152(f)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. For tax purposes, a custodial parent is defined as the one who provides over half of the child's support during the year. This designation allows the child to be considered a qualifying individual for tax benefits. The child must receive over half of their support from parents who never married and lived apart during the last six months of the year. The child must also be in the custody of one or both parents for more than half of the year. Amendments to this section apply to taxable years starting in 2002 and 2011. The amendments to this section apply to taxable years starting in 2002 and 2011. The act provides for a tax levy and shall go into immediate effect.
